participants.participant: Friedrich Lauer, Vice President, Head of Investor Relations
Bodo Uebber, Finance & Controlling and Daimler Financial Services

plist.p: Welcome to the Global Conference Call of Daimler. At our customer's request, this conference will be recorded. You can listen to the replay by dialing the numbers you will find on your invitation. The replay of the conference call with indexation and synchronized presentation slides will also be available as audio webcast on demand in the Investor Relations section of the Daimler website. The conference will be followed by a question-and-answer session. .
May I now hand over to Mr. Friedrich Lauer, Head of Daimler Investor Relations. Thank you very much.

Good afternoon from Stuttgart. This is Friedrich Lauer from Daimler Investor Relations. On behalf of Daimler, I would like to welcome you on both the telephone and the Internet to our first quarter results presentation.

Bodo Uebber, Member of the Board of Management of Daimler, responsible for Finance & Controlling and Daimler Financial Services, will start with a presentation and will be happy to take your questions afterwards.

Before we start, I have the usual administrative details. The interim report, the fact sheet, and the slides to accompany this conference call are available on our website. I would like to remind you that this teleconference is governed by the Safe Harbor wording that you'll find in our published results documents.

Please note that our presentations contain forward-looking statements that reflect management's current views with respect to future events. These forward-looking statements can be identified by expressions such as anticipate, assume, believe, estimate, expect, intend, may, plan, project or should. Such statements are subject to risks and uncertainties, examples of which are set out in the Safe Harbor wording in our documents and are also described in our most recent Form 20-F under the heading Risk Factors. If the assumptions underlying any of these statements prove incorrect, then the actual results may be materially different from those expressed or implied by such statements. And forward-looking statements speak only to the date on which they are made.
Now I would like to hand over the conference to Bodo Uebber.
Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to welcome you to our Q1 results conference call. Let me turn directly to the figures.

In the first quarter of 2008, we sold approximately 504,000 vehicles, 9% more than in the year before. However, more important than this key number is the fact that Mercedes-Benz Cars and our Vans and Buses units achieved their highest sales volume ever in the first quarter at strong EBIT numbers. Group revenue at €23.5 billion was almost exactly at the level of the previous year. Adjusted for exchange rate effects and changes in the consolidated group, revenue increased by 4%.

We achieved a strong EBIT of €2 billion which reflects an increase in EBIT of 45% to €1.2 billion at Mercedes-Benz Cars. Daimler Trucks and Daimler Financial Services recorded EBIT figures lower than in the previous year but in light of the challenges these divisions currently face these are quite remarkable results.

The EBIT of our Vans, Bus, Other segment includes the gain of €449 million from the sale of our real estate at Potsdamer Platz and charges of €491 million related to Chrysler. Please note that the charges related to Chrysler had no cash impact. The EBIT of the first quarter of 2008 includes a gain of €0.1 billion from the transfer of interest in EADS compared to €1.6 billion in the prior year quarter.

On chart 3, you can see the key figures for the first quarter in comparison to last year's results. Net profit at €1.3 billion was significantly lower than the €2 billion in 2007 which included the tax-free gain of the EADS transaction. The free cash flow of our industrial business was €1 billion. The net liquidity of our industrial business was at a level of €11.7 billion at the end of the quarter, thus only €1.2 billion below the year-end level despite our share buyback of €2.7 billion during Q1 2008.

Let me now turn to the divisional results, starting with Mercedes-Benz Cars on chart number 4. The division's unit sales increased by 17% to 318,000 vehicles reflecting strong growth of 10% for Mercedes-Benz passenger cars and for smart sales, which almost tripled to 31,000 units. The S-Class was once again the clear market leader in the luxury segment. Deliveries of the C-Class rose by 57% to 113,000 vehicles. The C-Class sedan was market leader in its segment.

Sales were especially strong in the NAFTA region and in Asia boosted mainly by China. At €12.5 million revenue exceeded last year's level by 4%. The higher unit sales overcompensated for the negative exchange rate effects in the less favorable bottlenecks. Adjusted for exchange rate effects revenue increased by 7%.

Chart number 5 shows the development of EBIT. The EBIT of Mercedes-Benz Cars rose by 45% to €1.2 billion. This corresponds to a return on sales of 9.2% compared to 6.6% in the first quarter of 2007. This steep increase reflects the market success of our products both at Mercedes-Benz passenger cars and at smart. In addition, our efficiency enhancement measures continue to payoff. Long-term structural and process-oriented improvements have been and continue to be implemented in the line organization. On the other hand, EBIT was negatively impacted by exchange rate effects from the continued weakness of the U.S. dollar and by higher raw material prices.

As far as new products are concerned, we keep moving forward. In January, Mercedes-Benz presented the Vision of the GLK and the new generation of the SLK at the Detroit Auto Show. Shortly after that, we unveiled the new CLC Coupe with its very fuel-efficient turbo diesel engines. At the beginning of March, we presented the new generations of the SL Roadster and the CLS 4-Door Coupe, which are now even more attractive as a result of various design and technical changes. And we also remained in the driver's seat with respect to our BlueTec models. At the New York Auto Show, we unveiled the R 320, the ML 320 and the GL BlueTec versions. Thanks to their modern diesel engines, all three of these vehicles fulfilled the US Bin 5 emission limits and also have the potential to meet the future Euro 6 standards.

Let's now turn to Daimler Trucks. The Truck division sold 108,000 vehicles worldwide, 10% fewer than in the prior year quarter. The Trucks Europe, Latin America units sold 34,000 vehicles in the first quarter, once again achieving the high level of the prior year quarter. A production loss due to a supplier's production downtime caused unit sales in Western Europe to be lower than in Q1 2007. We assume, however, that we will be able to compensate for this production loss before the end of this year.

Due to the economic slowdown in the U.S., Trucks NAFTA continued to suffer from the weak demand for trucks in the U.S. and Canada and sold 27,000 vehicles. This was 40% fewer than in the prior year quarter, also because the first quarter of 2007 was the last strong quarter before the market contraction related to the new emission regulation, EPA 07.

Trucks Asia increased its first quarter unit sales by 18% to 46,000 units. Fortwo suffered from weak demand in its home market. Fortwo international business however showed strong growth. Revenue of €6.3 billion was 13% lower than in 2007 resulting from the sharp market decline in the NAFTA region and also from the weakness of the U.S. dollar. Adjusted for exchange rate effects, revenue decreased by 9%.

The unfavorable market situation in the U.S. reflecting a difficult economic environment and sales resistance as a result of the new emission standards introduced in 2007 caused negative impacts on Daimler Trucks earnings. An additional impact on the earnings came from the units we lost due to the production downtimes at one of our suppliers, which are expected to be compensated over the rest of the year. Although these costs could not be compensated by higher volumes in Latin America and Asia, positive effects resulted from our efficiency improvements and the better product positioning. Nevertheless, we achieved a return on sales of 6.4% in the first quarter and in light of the market situation we think that is not a bad result.

On the next slide, you can see our new Mercedes-Benz Actros. We unveiled the third generation of our flagship in the heavy-duty business in January. This vehicle has been further improved with a large number of individual modifications affecting economy, comfort and design. Since the launch of the first generation of the Actros in 1996 more than 550,000 units of this vehicle have been sold in over 100 countries.

With the Mercedes-Benz Atego BlueTec Hybrids and the Mitsubishi Fuso Canter Eco Hybrid, the first hybrid trucks were handed over to the European customers. This confirms our leading position with regard to hybrid trucks and buses.

Now, let's turn to our Van operations shown at chart number 10. In the first quarter of 2008, the Mercedes-Benz Vans unit sold 69,000 vehicles setting a new sales record for the quarter. This was above all the result of strong demand for the Sprinter of which we sold 42,000 units between January and March, 18% more than the prior year. The higher sales volume also led to a significant increase in revenue to €2.3 billion.

In light of the growing relative share of the Van and Bus business within the Daimler Group, we have decided to start disclosing the EBIT figures for van and buses. Vans achieved an EBIT of €168 million, reflecting a very positive sales development. Daimler Buses, which is shown on slide 11, sold 9,200 buses and chassis and therefore, surpassed last year's volume by 11%. Both Latin America, mainly driven by the market development in Brazil and Western Europe contributed to this favorable development with double-digit growth rates. As a consequence of the growth in volume, our Bus business also increased its revenue to €919 million, 13% more as in the first quarter in 2007. The EBIT of Daimler Buses for the first quarter was €75 million.

Some of the Bus and Van products are shown on slide 12, including the new Setra TopClass 400 Bus we started to deliver in January. The Setra TopClass 400 features a variety of technical innovations and optical improvements and is our most important product innovation in the Bus business this year.

The EBIT development of Vans, Buses, and Other segment is shown on slide 13. The overall earnings of the segment were €371 million, compared to €1.9 billion in the prior year quarter. The segment EBIT in 2008 includes a gain of €449 million from the sale of our real estate complex at Potsdamer Platz in Berlin. The Q1 2008 figure also includes a gain of €0.1 billion from the sale of our non-strategic EADS holding, the so-called excess shares. In the prior year the EBIT of the Vans, Buses, and Other segment included €1.6 billion related to the reduction of our equity investment in EADS.

EADS itself contributed €22 million to our EBIT. In the prior year EADS results from ongoing business was €279 million. In addition, Q1 2007 had been impacted by €114 million due to the restructuring. Further burdens on EBIT resulted from our stake in Chrysler, which are shown on slide 14.

At the beginning of April, the IT systems of Daimler Financial Services and Chrysler Financial were separated. We have thus now completed the separation from Chrysler Financials activities from both a technical and a legal point of view. In addition, the international Chrysler sales organization has been separated and the Chrysler-related sales activities have been placed into new companies. These companies have been prepared to transfer to Chrysler.

In the first quarter, the EBIT impact resulting from Chrysler was €0.5 billion. Please note that this has no cash effect. This includes charges of €246 million from the ongoing business and additional, mainly restructuring-related special reporting items in the amount of €94 million. These figures mainly reflect developments at Chrysler in the fourth quarter of 2007. However, please note that these results are by no means indicative for the results further reported by Chrysler – to be reported by Chrysler Holding LLC due to substantial valuation differences between U.S. GAAP used by Chrysler and IFRS accounting used by Daimler.

In addition, charges of €151 million resulted from the impairment of rights related to residual values of Chrysler vehicles. This asset reflect the rights to participate in residual value gains of Chrysler leasing vehicles at the end of the lease term and had to be written down due to decline of used car prices. As of March 31, 2008, the book value of our share in Chrysler Holding decreased to €547 million. Outstanding guarantees provided by Daimler were reduced by 0.3 billion to US $0.7 billion. Correspondingly, the collateral provided by Chrysler on an escrow account decreased by 0.1 billion to $0.4 billion.

Let's now turn to Daimler Financial Services. The contract volume of our Financial Services business increased by 2% to €58.3 billion. Adjusted for exchange rate effects and changes in the consolidated group, the increase was 7%. In the first quarter, we started to consolidate 15 more financial services companies, mainly in Eastern Europe and Asia. Approximately one-third of our portfolio is in the Americas region and two-thirds is in the rest of the world. A €16 billion portfolio is managed by the Mercedes-Benz Bank in Germany.
New business in the first quarter amounted to €6.7 billion. This was 2% below the prior year. Adjusted for exchange rate effects and changes in the consolidated group the decrease was also 2%.

Our earnings, however, continued to be negatively impacted by the expenses to be incurred for the development of a new Financial Services organization in the NAFTA region. As shown on slide 16, the EBIT of our Financial Services division was €168 million compared to €214 million in the prior year quarter. Higher cost of risk due to the economic slowdown mainly in the U.S. also had negative impacts on the reported earnings. Nevertheless, our cost of risk still remains below the long-term average.

Coming back to the Group level, now let's take a look at the net profit and earnings per share. Net profit was lower than in the first quarter of 2007. This is partially due to the lower EBIT and also results from the fact that the gain on the transfer of interest in EADS in the prior year was not taxable and had thus boosted net profit. In Q1 2008 we had tax expense of €674 million compared to €711 million in the prior year quarter. Earnings per share in Q1 amounted to €1.29.

Our key balance sheet and financial figures are shown on chart 18. Compared to the end of the 2007, we further decreased our gross liquidity from €17.1 billion to €11.7 billion. This still includes a dividend, which has distributed after the Annual Meeting in early April. We are still in the process of melting down our excess liquidity, which resulted from the cash inflow in connection with the Chrysler transaction. The net liquidity of our industrial business of €11.7 billion was €1.2 billion lower than at the year-end but still at a very high level, despite the €2.7 billion used for the share buyback in February and March. With cash inflows of €1.3 billion, net liquidity was positively impacted by the sale of the Potsdamer Platz complex.

The Group's equity ratio adjusted for the dividend payment was 26.9% and thus reflected that at the level of the year-end 2007. The equity ratio of our industrial business increased from 43.5% to 44.9%.

For the first three months, the free cash flow of the industrial business was €1 billion compared to €2.9 billion for the prior year period which still contained a cash inflow of €3.5 billion from the transfer of interest in EADS. The current year figure includes proceeds from the sale of the real estate complex at Potsdamer Platz yielding an amount of €1.3 billion. The cash flow was impacted by an increase in inventories at Mercedes-Benz Car, a usual pattern to prepare for the spring selling season.

Slide 19 summarizes the effects of the share buyback program we executed between August 2007 and March 2008. In total we bought back 100 million shares equivalent to €6.2 billion. The second tranche which started after our Annual Press Conference on February 14 comprised 50 million shares equivalent to €2.7 billion. We canceled all treasury shares prior to the Annual Meeting and got a new approval from our shareholders in April. Our steps to optimize the Group's capital structure will be continued. The timing will depend not only on the Group's cash flows and net liquidity but also on the developments in the capital markets.
Our excess liquidity resulting from the Chrysler transaction is currently used to repay maturing liabilities and, therefore, will be further reduced during the course of the second quarter.

Given the current conditions of the financial markets, with spreads for new debts at extremely high levels and the uncertainty regarding the potential impact on the real economy, it is reasonable to use excess funds for our Financial Services for a certain period of time. As soon as we return to normal capital market conditions we will decide on further measures to optimize our capital structure. This target is still committed and on our agenda.

Now let me turn to our expectations for the year 2008 as a whole. The economic development is currently subject to many uncertainties. Market expectations have been reduced, especially for the three major sales regions and above all the passenger car volume segments. It can be assumed that overall demand for passenger cars will be significantly lower than in 2007 in the United States, will remain flat in Western Europe and will rise only slightly in Japan.

With regard to markets for commercial vehicles, we expect moderate growth of the overall European market due to the robust development of demand for medium and heavy trucks. In North American market, we do not see any signs of recovery at present. We, therefore, assume that the cyclical recovery of demand for trucks will commence at the earliest in the second half of the year.

Although we, although the overall economic picture became more cloudy and the automotive industry including Daimler currently faces more headwinds, we confirm our sales targets communicated on February 14, 2008, when we presented our 2007 figures. We assume that Mercedes-Benz Cars will continue increasing its worldwide unit sales in 2008. Daimler Trucks are expected to rise unit sales in 2008 compared to the prior year reflecting positive developments in unit sales in some Asian markets and Europe. We still expect a recovery of unit sales in the NAFTA region. However, this depends on the overall development of the economy in the U.S.
For the Mercedes-Benz Vans unit, we anticipate a continued rise in unit sales, mainly due to the new Sprinter. And for Daimler Buses, we expect unit sales to remain stable on a very high level.

What does all of that mean for our earning strength? Mercedes-Benz Cars continues to anticipate a further increase in EBIT. We will effectively pursue our policy of continued efficiency improvements and we will continue inspiring our customers with fascinating products. At Daimler Trucks, further efficiency enhancements in combination with the anticipated higher unit sales should increase earnings once again in 2008.

At Daimler Financial Services, we are aiming to achieve a return on equity of at least 40% also in the year 2008 despite the expenses for setting up our own Financial Services organization in NAFTA, in North America.

Let me add here that we are, of course, well aware of the financial crisis and its potential impact for the real economy. Nevertheless, on the basis of the divisions' projections, which we confirmed today, we expect Daimler to post 2008 EBIT from ongoing operations of well above the prior year level. However, effects related to Chrysler are not included therein.
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for your attention. I will now be happy to answer your questions.

Thank you very much, Bodo Uebber. Ladies and gentlemen, you may ask your questions now. I will identify the questioner by name, but please also introduce yourself with your name and the name of the organization that you are representing before asking your questions. Two practical points, firstly, please avoid using a mobile phone, as this disturbs the quality of the call for everyone, and secondly, please ask your questions in English. Before we start the session, the operator will explain the procedure.
Okay, ladies and gentlemen, we take the first question today from . Please go ahead.

Yes, good afternoon. I have three questions, if I may. First of all, on the Truck division, I wonder whether you could clarify within the first quarter or at least specify how much the production hold hit your earnings. Was this a low triple-digit number or is this too high? And secondly, on the Truck side, in Western Europe we are seeing throughout the industry that orders are decelerating, I understand from a phenomenally high level but could you maybe help us how we should see the year progressing and especially with a light on 2009 is it fair to assume that the truck industry will see its peak in Western Europe in 2008?

And secondly, as you would expect on Financial Services, could you give us an update on where you stand with regards to leased assets, residual value assumptions, how it works at Daimler, when would you be forced to take charges similar to BMW that we've just heard? And lastly, also with regards to Financial Services, where do we stand with refinancing conditions, how are credit market conditions for Daimler? And with a light on share buybacks, would you say that currently the situation is back to normal that you would commence your share buyback program or are we not yet there? Thank you.

, thank you for your questions. That was a lot of questions, so let me start with your first one regarding the Truck unit and the impact of the production downtime we had. We are currently – we are speaking about 6 to 7,000 unit in the first quarter. We do assume that we can offset these 6 to 7,000 units during the course of the year. The overall impact is roughly say two-digit, three-digit number, it's €100 million roughly, 110 precisely, but €100 million is a fair number for the first quarter.

Secondly, you asked for the order intake development. First of all, I have to say I am happy with the order intake development. We have minus 16%, somewhat in the first quarter but as you said on a very high level. It is to say that if you compare this with other competitors numbers even, let's say this kind of decrease is even a better one and we have to state that also all our order backlog is together with this number further increasing, so that means our – we are now in seven to eight months of giving orders out. And so I am pretty happy with that situation. Overall, we expect the market in total to be positively together with Eastern Europe, so Western Europe together with Eastern Europe should contribute fairly positive.

We had also three days in orders, Eastern was not a very favorable month this year for March, so I am overall happy. We do see also not any cancellations as other might has announced it. We have a very conservative as always I do think so, how to count order intakes. Our next year's numbers, of course, it depends a lot of the overall economic development. As far as today I am seeing that we have not reached big issue from U.S. coming over to Europe. And as far as the Eastern European markets are fairly increasing also next year and Middle East is doing its contribution I would even say that for next year we have a positive, let's say, market development. Whether that goes slightly down and slightly up we will tell you, of course, in February 2009.

So your last question with regard to residuals and our impacts here and the question compared to P&L, of course, I do not make any comparison to BMW at first hand, but I can state we are sufficiently covered with our provisions and write-offs we have done on the credit side and also on the residual value side. When we go back to the residual values, for example, in revising of – we very early took measures in 2006, when I remember right, when we changed our – some of our philosophies, when we changed also processes in terms of how to get the cars back. I do think we are very conservatively in setting the residual values on the one hand. We are also better, I would say even than last year in optimizing the structure between lease maturities getting to auctions and lease maturities getting to dealers. It's roughly – we are 10 percentage points better in this regard to less to the auctions which have the residual values and I do think our conservative approach in this regard helps up too. So we saw, of course, a deteriorating in the first quarter. We have applied, of course, the whole situation to March for our residual value setting process we do have which we do each quarter. And that's it, so you don't see us here posting any one-time charge-offs or anything. So we doing our job each quarter in this regard and I do think from our risk management processes and fine.

The question is I do think you will raise the second question, okay, what does happen when it further goes down? We even think that we are – they are also somewhat protected. Of course, you cannot exclude worst-case scenarios. But you have also to see a little bit of a seasonality in the residual values when you look at the Mannheim index, for example, you see some, of course, some seasonality in this regard. So what I said, you have to look at this closely but I do think we are very reserved in this regard.
And on the share buyback, sorry on credit...?

...on the share buyback refinancing. Currently of course, it's expensive to go outside into the market, so it means our commitment to optimize our capital structure is our commitment, so our target is clear. We have announced it and we stayed through this target. But right now it does not make sense that we go into the market for a couple of billion refinancing and take in the high spreads which we have today even that we got upgraded by Standard & Poor's. But EBIT comes down again, we will look at the very best point of time and then to come a little bit by surprise as always you know to come back to further do our, let's say, optimization of the capital structure.
All right, thank you.
Georges Dieng would you please ask next question.

Oh hello, good afternoon. I have several questions. First of all, a follow-up on the Financial Services, could you maybe be more specific in terms of the cost of risk. You mentioned that it has deteriorated but it's still below the long-term benchmark, but could you put some figure on that? And also have you seen an increase in the delinquency, especially in North America? And also the issue of refinancing cost, to what extent this cost have increased in the first quarter for Financial Services?

I have a second one on Chrysler. The remaining book value is now at 547 million, if I am correct. Would it not be safer to impair the entirety of this remaining equity value? And a final question on Mercedes, if you could maybe elaborate a bit on the hedging policy, where you stand today towards both the dollar and the pound? And in the earnings walk down, which is more qualitative than quantitative, could you put a figure on the raw material impact and maybe the expected burden for the full year? Thank you.

A couple of questions. So let me start with, Georges, with the first one. Regarding the credit losses, we have in first quarter globally, now globally talking, 0.48%, so 48 basis points in terms of credit losses, which compares to Q1 2007 of 0.33. That's 33 basis points, which was over the year, total year, 39 basis points. And, of course, this reflects a development in the U.S., which deteriorated somewhat in the first quarter. That you can see, of course, within for example, our Truck business EBIT. Mercedes-Benz in the U.S. was even a little bit positive in terms of repossessions, for example, in the first quarter, but of course, from this kind of trends you cannot make up the total year development. But you also can see slight tendency of increasing delinquencies in Europe and the other countries but by far, as I said right now, it is not at the long-term average. And if you take the number of 48 basis points, I do think you can make your comparisons.

Your second question was the Financial Services cost. Of course, as of today it's very positive because we don't have to go to the capital markets. That means that our financial expenses for the Financial Services business in this regard is not impacted by the kind of financial crisis you see in the U.S. and across the board because we had this excess liquidity from Chrysler. In '08 arms length, behavior to Financial Services, we rate Financial Services with market rates in their expenses.

Regarding Chrysler, you stated rightly that we have a book value of 547 million and you asked okay, why don't you write it off? Honestly, my answer is, if I could do it maybe but there are rules and regulations, of course I have to apply and there are also -- also are auditors which have to, let's say, look at the stuff. So this reflects right now equity consolidation of Chrysler, so means when Chrysler done some early development and here we have to account IFRS and not U.S. GAAP and there are certain different evaluations of certain subjects. So it hits then our equity, then it hits our book value and that is what it reflects. So you – and as long as we say that this value – at this value these hits which we have are non-cash impacts and, therefore, the value – overall value of Chrysler even if you see the actions of the management they take are more, let's say, in the right way of increasing our value in this state, so there is no reason to write it off to zero or to a different number than we have stated.

Your fourth question was do our hedging policies have not changed Of course, the question, as you know, whether I do some hedges when the dollar is at 1.59, so it is the same number we had at February 14. It's roughly 80%. It's the same number as of February. And I stated also at the Press Conference that we have roughly 40% in 2009 and these are more or less the same numbers for the British pound. It's also 80% and roughly 40% in 2009.
Next question from Arndt Ellinghorst please.

Good afternoon. Arndt Ellinghorst from Credit Suisse. Two questions, the first one is on Mercedes. Normally there's a certain seasonality in the profitability of that business, with I guess better profitability in Q2 and Q4 moving forward. Has there been anything special in the first quarter that you came up with such a strong margin or should we expect a similar pattern as normal for the remainder of the year? And secondly, on residual values again, could you just clarify how you markdown your residual values in the year? Do you mark them down end of March or do you mark them down on an average Q1 residual value assumption?

Your second question is a very interesting one because I do think you would like us to draw a comparison to some other who disclosed the numbers as of today. Honestly, we are looking at the total situation of January, February, March, so there is no average discussion. So even if your residuals are going down in March, you have to consider it for the impairments you have to take or you have not to take. So you cannot work in this regard. So we are working on the total situation including the March situation, so end March is the answer. The total March includes also the end of March. If you mean the – I don't know whether there was a 31st, whether it was a Sunday, I don't know but the total months development.

As I said before, we do that very conservatively. We have introduced many, many measures years ago. We are aware of lease maturities. We are aware that the stock is coming back. And as I said before, we are optimizing the total structure and we were successful with that. Compared to last year, we could reduce the auction volume, which is absolutely positive because there you get, of course, the worst prices. If you go to a dealer, of course, it's better. And we have a cushion in our lease rates regarding conservative residual value and, therefore, we have done our stuff this quarter as we have done it last quarter and the quarters before in all our looking at the residual values, necessary impairments or whatever.

Your first question would be for the normally development of Q1 to Q2, Q3, Q4, I would answer this question more or less yes. Was there anything special in Q1? I would say, no, as the once we have already discussed about the U.S. dollar. Of course, if you mean that it it's something special, of course, it is special in this way. If we get to 2009 and 10, of course, if it would stay at the current level, of course, your hedges are going down and therefore, of course, you might have better, let's say, hedge rates in the first quarter than in 2009 first quarter. Therefore, of course, you could mean that it's somewhat special. As material prices, raw material prices have also their, their impact – therefore, there was a question, I think two questions before which I have not really answered, so there are impacts but we are able right now on a net approach to compensate this with net savings.
Thanks a lot.
Next question from Adam Jonas please.

Good evening. It's Adam Jonas from Morgan Stanley. Two questions, if I may. First, on the North American truck orders, up 80% in North America and in the USA specifically year-on-year, how much of this growth in orders is due to the Mexican situation ahead of the June, July pre-buy, how much of it is just reaching dreadfully easy comparisons or is there any even a slight heart beat of a recovery although I know you have already addressed that last point.

Second question, you have mentioned in some statements in the past and most recently around the release of your annual report that you'll keep your options open for cash usage including perhaps investments in batteries, electronics and powertrain-related investments. Is there any rationale for you to consider making an investment in companies that do those kinds of things through either a minority investment or something greater than a minority investment? Thank you.

To the last answer, you know, we have the same opinion as we had in February, yes, of course. Adam, yes, we hold true to our strategy. If there are any, let's say, opportunities in this regard, investment-wise up and down the value chain, we are looking at this stuff and, of course, that we have always said, besides doing good products and investments we are open in this area. But, of course, right now it's early to say in areas like batteries and other stuff to say something there is nothing, which I can now say whether we have a target of something like this.

Your question regarding NAFTA, I'm a little bit difficult with the question on Mexico. I do think I need to tell you that you have to call Friedrich Lauer and we'll look for this question because here on hand I have not the information about this. Regarding NAFTA, especially we have not a bad order intake. So I'd say it's a little bit better but, of course, it's not a trend. We don't see yet a trend that the order intakes gets better now for the second quarter, so it remains as it is. We had some good order intakes in fourth quarter but these were special deals, one deal or two deals, which you see the numbers are a little bit down again in the first quarter, so the situation is as it was in February, no new information.
Okay, thanks very much.
Okay.
We take the next question from Adam Hull please.

Hi, good afternoon. Because we give you a value at the end, it's nothing else in determining a lease rate on the one hand and the lease rate on the one hand does also with residual value, a combination to the price positioning of the product.
